The focal point of a lens is not where the light converges, is where the light coming "from the infinite" or at least from far away, converges. The sun is far away enought, so the light of the sun converges in the focal point. The distance between the focal point and the lens is the focal distance.

One trick if you're well and truly used to being in the woods is to look for fallen branches or trunks (like 3" diameter or larger) that have been weathering for a long time. The good stuff is wood that is very soft, spongy and light and dry. It resembles driftwood a bit, but much softer, kind of like the springyness of packing foam. It will literally burn like a cigarette. All you have to do is hit it for a bit with your magnifying glass to get a small ember going, then add a bit of wind from a breeze or your breath, and presto, fire, baby. The stuff is so good at it that if you have any real wind, it WILL catch fire with just a tiny starter coal growing fast and then igniting. With a little luck you can find large chunks of it everywhere in an uncleared woodland, and just add some to your pack or whatever to keep you well stocked for starting several fires on just a reasonable block about 3" long. Break off a little piece, start an ember on it, and blow on it hard till it ignites.

When I was a kid, I was an f***in' artist with magnifying lenses and fire, lol. Small Fresnel lenses are my favorite (try a full page magnifier sometime for a hell of a thrill, you can make bits of glass from sand!), but I really have to admire this baggie trick for pure genius.

This is really just another version of the "Plastic Magnifying Glass" firestarter.
Maybe it'd actually be interesting if you broke down the plastic into a substance that ignites through friction, like a match.
Course, anything that would ignite with such a little amount of energy would either be a gas or completely fictional.
Maybe a chemical fire, hmm? Something that undergoes spontaneous combustion on contact with plastic? No. Such a substance would react with quite literally anything, from the air we breath to the container that you might try to use to contain it. The fire wouldn't start from the plastic, thus the plastic bag would not be a firestarter.
Electricity? Sure. Whatever. That's plasma. Basically already "Fire" at that point. So that's cheating.
Maybe you could make some sort of fire piston with the bag eh?
Anyone who's ever popped a bag of chips knows it's pretty loud, oughta be able to start something in there right?
No. Very little heat would actually be created, far to little to even consider starting a fire even at extreme pressures. The volume can be decreased, but the elasticity of the plastic bag would allow the pressure to decrease as well, and vice versa. Besides, it'd be a one use apparatus and it'd be to difficult to keep the kindling when it's wrapped in plastic.
Plastic Lasers? Basically a different kind of magnifying glass, only changes the light.
High current/Voltage/Resistance Circuitry to create enough heat to start a fire?
Again, even if it's inside a plastic case, it's still basically fire already.

This is so stupid. For one, if there is ANY wind you won't be able to keep your tinder from blowing away. Secondly, you can blow on the fire bundle and it will ignite MUCH faster.

like most "survival" tricks on YouTube, this is less useful than you might think and more complicated than is necessary.
First, it requires that you have a sandwich bag with you, it be day-time when you do it, and that it's also sunny. Unfortunately, none of those are likely to be the case in a survival situation, because if you have any of those things, you're probably NOT in a survival situation. chances are if you have sandwich bags, you also have everything else needed. Not that it can't happen, of course, and maybe you just want to save limited resources for when it's raining. usually though, you don't need a fire during the day when it's sunny... you'd be doing any traveling you need to do during the day while you can, which means babysitting a fire is out of the question
Second, you can just puddle the water in the bag on the flat side and it automatically is a lens, you don't need to go through all that business of making it spherical... YouTube GreenPowerScience does a lot with lenses, including water lenses and home built parabolic mirrors
